title: Brighton, Hartland in rematch; Howell to Grand Ledge
text:
Brighton, Hartland in rematch; Howell to Grand Ledge Tim Robinson, Livingston Daily 9:29 p.m. EDT October 25, 2015 Brighton coach Brian Lemons gathers his thoughts before addressing his team Sunday night. The Bulldogs will play host to Hartland in Friday's playoff opener. (Photo: Tim Robinson/Livingston Daily) 56 CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
BRIGHTON -- After mounds of pizza and seemingly acres of pizza were consumed, the Brighton football team, like hundreds across the state, settled in to watch Sunday's selection show inside a baseball training room at the Legacy Center in Green Oak Township. 
The Bulldogs had to wait for nearly an hour, then learned they would face the opponent they had figured to see all along. 
Of the three Livingston County teams playing in the postseason, Brighton will be the only team playing host to a playoff game. 
The Bulldogs (8-1) will be taking on the Hartland Eagles (6-3), who beat them 14-7 at Hartland earlier this month. 
They are in the same district bracket as Howell (5-4), which will begin make its first playoff since 2012 at Grand Ledge (9-0). 
Brighton coach Brian Lemons said his team's game will be played at 7 p.m. Friday, which is when most first-round games are played, but the time and date won't be official until the Michigan High School Athletic Association releases the schedule Monday morning. 
"Getting in is the most important part," Lemons said. "After that, whomever they give you, that's what you get." 
"We're going to have our work cut out for us," Hartland coach Brian Savage said. "We have some film against them, which is better than not knowing what to expect. It's a short bus trip, and we're just happy to be playing in a playoff game and not just watching." 
"I was hoping it would be Hartland," Brighton senior Joey Clifford said. "Ever since we lost to them, I was hoping to play them again." 
Howell coach Aaron Metz's team had thought for a moment it would miss the playoffs after injuries ruined a 5-1 start. 
The Highlanders were helped by one of the largest fields for 5-4 teams in recent memory. A total of 40 teams with that record got into the playoffs this year; many years it's less than a dozen. 
All that, however, was ancient history the moment the pairings flashed onto TV screens across the state. 
"We played Grand Ledge in 2010, so there's a little history," Metz said. "It's good to be playing somewhere different, but most importantly it's an opportunity. We'll take any matchup we can and go for it." 
Grand Ledge has the top seed the next two weeks, so it could play host to Hartland in a rematch of last year's playoff game between the teams, which the Comets won 21-0 on a snowy Halloween night. 
Grand Ledge also has played Brighton in the playoffs, the last time in 2000 when the Comets held off a powerful Bulldogs team and went on to win the state championship. 
At the beginning of the century, coaches got together to watch the show and players watched at their homes. These days, it's a team event. 
"We watched film from Friday, then the selection show," said Savage, who had his team gathered at Hartland High School, as in the past. "The kids went home, and the coaches are here trying to get stuff done." 
Howell also gathered at the high school to watch on a projection TV in the field house. 
"I like it better than going out to watch the show," Metz said. "It's a good team-building atmosphere, and it was kind of a cool setting, just our players and coaches." 
Brighton coach Brian Lemons, in white cap, is surrounded by players while watching Sunday's MHSAA playoff selection show at the Legacy Center. (Photo: Tim Robinson/Livingston Daily)
